text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
MessageHeader DomainResourceA resource that describes a message that is exchanged between systems
identifier 1..1idId of this message
timestamp 1..1instantTime that the message was sent
event M1..1CodingCode for the event this message represents
MessageEvent (Incomplete)
response M0..1ElementIf this is a reply to prior message
identifier 1..1idId of original message
code M1..1codeok | transient-error | fatal-error
ResponseType (Required)
details 0..1OperationOutcomeSpecific list of hints/warnings/errors
source 1..1ElementMessage Source Application
name 0..1stringName of system
software 0..1stringName of software running the system
version 0..1stringVersion of software running
contact 0..1ContactPointHuman contact for problems
endpoint 1..1uriActual message source address or id
destination 0..*ElementMessage Destination Application(s)
name 0..1stringName of system
target 0..1DeviceParticular delivery destination within the destination
endpoint 1..1uriActual destination address or id
enterer 0..1PractitionerThe source of the data entry
author 0..1PractitionerThe source of the decision
receiver 0..1Practitioner | OrganizationIntended "real-world" recipient for the data
responsible 0..1Practitioner | OrganizationFinal responsibility for event
reason 0..1CodeableConceptCause of event
EventReason (Example)
data 0..*AnyThe actual content of the message

element.short: A resource that describes a message that is exchanged between systems
element.formal: The header for a message exchange that is either requesting or responding to an action.  The Reference(s) that are the subject of the action as well as other Information related to the action are typically transmitted in a bundle in which the MessageHeader resource instance is the first resource in the bundle.
element.requirements: Many implementations are not prepared to use REST and need a messaging based infrastructure.

element.formal: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resoure. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.formal: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the url. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comments: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

element.short: When the resource version last changed
element.formal: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comments: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.formal: A list of profiles that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to Profile.url.
element.comments: It is up to the server and/or other infrastruture of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over tiem.

element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.formal: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comments: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.formal: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comments: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.formal: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: The identifier of this message.
element.comments: This SHALL be unique within the scope of this stream of messages.

element.short: Time that the message was sent
element.formal: The time that the message was sent.
element.requirements: Allows limited detection of out-of-order and delayed transmission.  Also supports audit.

element.short: Code for the event this message represents
element.formal: Code that identifies the event this message represents and connects it with its definition. Events defined as part of the FHIR specification have the system value "http://hl7.org/fhir/message-type".
element.requirements: Drives the behavior associated with this message.

binding.name: MessageEvent
binding.description: One of the message events defined as part of FHIR

element.short: If this is a reply to prior message
element.formal: Information about the message that this message is a response to.  Only present if this message is a response.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: The id of the message that this message is a response to.
element.requirements: Allows receiver to know what message is being responded to.

element.formal: Code that identifies the type of response to the message - whether it was successful or not, and whether it should be resent or not.
element.comments: This is a generic response to the request message. Specific data for the response will be found in MessageHeader.data.
element.requirements: Allows the sender of the acknowledge message to know if the request was successful or if action is needed.

binding.name: ResponseType
binding.description: The kind of response to a message

element.formal: Full details of any issues found in the message.
element.comments: This SHALL be contained in the bundle. If any of the issues are errors, the response code SHALL be an error.
element.requirements: Allows the sender of the message to determine what the specific issues are.

element.formal: The source application from which this message originated.
element.requirements: Allows replies, supports audit.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: Human-readable name for the source system.
element.requirements: May be used to support audit.

element.short: Name of software running the system
element.formal: May include configuration or other information useful in debugging.
element.requirements: Supports audit and possibly interface engine behavior.

element.formal: Can convey versions of multiple systems in situations where a message passes through multiple hands.
element.requirements: Supports audit and possibly interface engine behavior.

mapping.map: SFT-2-software certified version or release number
SFT-2-software certified version or release number

element.formal: An e-mail, phone, website or other contact point to use to resolve issues with message communications.
element.requirements: Allows escalation of technical issues.

mapping.map: unique(./entity[determinerCode="INST" and classCode="DEV"]/scopesRole[normalRole() and classCode="CON" and layer[classCode="PSN"]/telecom[isNormalDatatype()])
unique(./entity[determinerCode="INST" and classCode="DEV"]/scopesRole[normalRole() and classCode="CON" and layer[classCode="PSN"]/telecom[isNormalDatatype()])

element.short: Actual message source address or id
element.formal: Identifies the routing target to send acknowledgements to.
element.comments: The id may be a non-resolvable URI for systems that do not use standard network-based addresses.
element.requirements: Identifies where to send responses, may influence security permissions.

element.formal: The destination application which the message is intended for.
element.comments: there SHOULD be at least one destination, but in some circumstances, the source system is unaware of any particular destination system.
element.requirements: Indicates where message is to be sent to for routing purposes.  Allows verification of "am I the intended recipient".

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: Human-readable name for the target system.
element.requirements: May be used for routing of response and/or to support audit.

element.short: Particular delivery destination within the destination
element.formal: Identifies the target end system in situations where the initial message transmission is to an intermediary system.
element.requirements: Supports multi-hop routing.

element.formal: Indicates where the message should be routed to.
element.comments: The id may be a non-resolvable URI for systems that do not use standard network-based addresses.
element.requirements: Identifies where to route the message.

mapping.map: MSH-25-receiving network address (or MSH-6-receiving facility by implication)
MSH-25-receiving network address (or MSH-6-receiving facility by implication)

element.short: The source of the data entry
element.formal: The person or device that performed the data entry leading to this message. Where there is more than one candidate, pick the most proximal to the message. Can provide other enterers in extensions.
element.comments: Usually only for the request, but can be used in a response.
element.requirements: Need to know for audit/traceback requirements and possibly for authorization.

mapping.map: EVN-5-operator ID / ORC-10-entered by / PRT-5-Participation Person:PRT-4-Participation='EP' / ROL where ROL.3 is EP or ORC.10

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[typeCode="ENT" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and determinerCode="INST"])
EVN-5-operator ID / ORC-10-entered by / PRT-5-Participation Person:PRT-4-Participation='EP' / ROL where ROL.3 is EP or ORC.10

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[typeCode="ENT" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and determinerCode="INST"])

element.formal: The logical author of the message - the person or device that decided the described event should happen. Where there is more than one candidate, pick the most proximal to the MessageHeader. Can provide other authors in extensions.
element.comments: Usually only for the request, but can be used in a response.
element.requirements: Need to know for audit/traceback requirements and possibly for authorization.

mapping.map: ORC-19-action by / PRT-5-Participation Person:PRT-4-Participation='AUT' / ROL where ROL.3 is IP or ORC.12

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="AUT" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and determinerCode="INST"])
ORC-19-action by / PRT-5-Participation Person:PRT-4-Participation='AUT' / ROL where ROL.3 is IP or ORC.12

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="AUT" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and determinerCode="INST"])

element.formal: Allows data conveyed by a message to be addressed to a particular person or department when routing to a specific application isn't sufficient.
element.requirements: Allows routing beyond just the application level.

mapping.map: Not directly supported.  Could be shared using attentionLine.value with an appropriate keyWordText
Not directly supported.  Could be shared using attentionLine.value with an appropriate keyWordText

element.formal: The person or organization that accepts overall responsibility for the contents of the message. The implication is that the message event happened under the policies of the responsible party.
element.comments: Usually only for the request, but can be used in a response.
element.requirements: Need to know for audit/traceback requirements and possibly for authorization.

mapping.map:
ORC-12-ordering provider / 
PRT-5-Participation Person:PRT-4-Participation='OP' / 
PRT-8-Participation Organization:PRT-4-Participation='OP'
/ ROL where ROL.3 is RO or ORC.11

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="RESP" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode="PSN" and determinerCode="INST"] or ./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="RESP" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/scoper[isNormalEntity() and classCode="ORG" and determinerCode="INST"])

ORC-12-ordering provider / 
PRT-5-Participation Person:PRT-4-Participation='OP' / 
PRT-8-Participation Organization:PRT-4-Participation='OP'
/ ROL where ROL.3 is RO or ORC.11

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="RESP" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode="PSN" and determinerCode="INST"] or ./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="RESP" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/scoper[isNormalEntity() and classCode="ORG" and determinerCode="INST"])

element.formal: Coded indication of the cause for the event - indicates  a reason for the occurance of the event that is a focus of this message.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track why resources are being changed and report in the audit log/history of the resource.  May affect authorization.

mapping.map: EVN.4 / ORC.16 / OBR-31-reason for study / BPO-13-BP indication for use / RXO-20-indication / RXE-27-give indication / RXD-21-indication / RXG-22-indication / RXA-19-indication
EVN.4 / ORC.16 / OBR-31-reason for study / BPO-13-BP indication for use / RXO-20-indication / RXE-27-give indication / RXD-21-indication / RXG-22-indication / RXA-19-indication

element.short: The actual content of the message
element.formal: The actual data of the message - a reference to the root/focus class of the event.
element.comments: The data is defined where the transaction type is defined. The transaction data is always included in the bundle that is the full message.  Only the root resource is specified.  The resources it references should be contained in the bundle but are not also listed here.  Multiple repetitions are allowed to cater for merges and other situations with multiple focal targets.
element.requirements: Every message event is about actual data, a single resource, that is identified in the definition of the event, and perhaps some or all linked resources.

mapping.map: unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role or ./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/outboundRelationship[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalActRelatoinship]/target)

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role or ./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/outboundRelationship[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalActRelatoinship]/target)

ORC-19-action by / PRT-5-Participation Person:PRT-4-Participation='AUT' / ROL where ROL.3 is IP or ORC.12

unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[isHighest(priorityCode) and typeCode="AUT" and isNormalParticipation]/role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole()]/player[isNormalEntity() and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and determinerCode="INST"])

element.formal: Allows data conveyed by a message to be addressed to a particular person or department when routing to a specific application isn't sufficient.
element.requirements: Allows routing beyond just the application level.

mapping.map: Not directly supported.  Could be shared using attentionLine.value with an appropriate keyWordText
Not directly supported.  Could be shared using attentionLine.value with an appropriate keyWordText

element.formal: The person or organization that accepts overall responsibility for the contents of the message. The implication is that the message event happened under the policies of the responsible party.
element.comments: Usually only for the request, but can be used in a response.
element.requirements: Need to know for audit/traceback requirements and possibly for authorization.

element.formal: Coded indication of the cause for the event - indicates  a reason for the occurance of the event that is a focus of this message.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track why resources are being changed and report in the audit log/history of the resource.  May affect authorization.

mapping.map: EVN.4 / ORC.16 / OBR-31-reason for study / BPO-13-BP indication for use / RXO-20-indication / RXE-27-give indication / RXD-21-indication / RXG-22-indication / RXA-19-indication
EVN.4 / ORC.16 / OBR-31-reason for study / BPO-13-BP indication for use / RXO-20-indication / RXE-27-give indication / RXD-21-indication / RXG-22-indication / RXA-19-indication

element.short: The actual content of the message
element.formal: The actual data of the message - a reference to the root/focus class of the event.
element.comments: The data is defined where the transaction type is defined. The transaction data is always included in the bundle that is the full message.  Only the root resource is specified.  The resources it references should be contained in the bundle but are not also listed here.  Multiple repetitions are allowed to cater for merges and other situations with multiple focal targets.
element.requirements: Every message event is about actual data, a single resource, that is identified in the definition of the event, and perhaps some or all linked resources.

mapping.map: unique(./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/participation[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role or ./controlAct[classCode="CACT" and classCode="EVN" and isNormalAct()]/outboundRelationship[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalActRelatoinship]/target)
